text:
Dissolution, and transfer of assets
	Dissolution of the Tote
		On the appointed day the Horserace Totalisator Board shall by virtue ofthis section cease to exist.
		In this Part “the appointed day” means a day appointed for the purposes ofthis section by the Secretary of State by order made by statutory instrument.
	Successor company: transfer
		All property, rights and liabilities to which the Horserace TotalisatorBoard was entitled or subject immediately before the appointed day shall onthat day vest in the successor company by virtue of this section.
		In this Part “the successor company” means a company which—
			is nominated for the purposes of this section by the Secretary of State inwriting before the appointed day, and
			on the appointed day is—
			a company formed and registered under the Companies Act [1985 (c.6)](/id/ukpga/1985/6?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") as a companylimited by shares, and
			wholly owned by the Crown.
	Sections 1 and 2: supplemental
		Anything done by or in relation to the Horserace Totalisator Board whichhas effect immediately before the appointed day shall continue to have effectas if done by or in relation to the successor company.
		Anything (including any legal proceedings) which immediately before theappointed day is in the process of being done by or in relation to the Boardmay be continued by or in relation to the successor company.
		So far as necessary or appropriate in consequence of section 2, on andafter the appointed day—
			a reference to the Board in an agreement (whether written or not),instrument or other document shall be treated as a reference to the successorcompany, and
			a reference in an agreement (whether written or not), instrument or otherdocument to a member or officer of the Board shall be treated as a referenceeither—
			to a person appointed for the purpose in writing by the successor company,or
			where no person is appointed under sub-paragraph (i), to the person whomost nearly corresponds in relation to the successor company to that member orofficer of the Board.
		The successor company shall provide information on request about anappointment under subsection (3)(b)(i).
		Section 2(1) shall operate in relation to property, rights or liabilities—
			whether or not they would otherwise be capable of being transferred by theBoard,
			without any instrument or other formality being required, and
			irrespective of any requirement for consent that would otherwise apply.
		In so far as section 2 transfers to the successor company liabilities undercontracts of employment—
			nothing in that section or this section shall affect the operation of theTransfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 1981 ([S.I.1981/1794](/id/uksi/1981/1794?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")), and
			the Secretary of State shall not appoint the appointed day unless satisfiedthat sufficient notice has been given to enable compliance with any applicablerequirement of those regulations.
		An order under section 1 may include consequential, incidental ortransitional provision.
		The Secretary of State shall consult the Board before nominating thesuccessor company.
		The Secretary of State shall consult the Board and the successor companybefore appointing the appointed day.
		A nomination under section 2(2)(a) may be revoked (and replaced) beforethe appointed day.
	Tax 
		For the purposes of any enactment about income tax, corporation tax orcapital gains tax—
			the successor company and the Horserace Totalisator Board shall be treatedas the same person, and
			in particular, the transfer effected by section 2 shall be disregarded.
		The transfer effected by section 2—
			shall be disregarded for the purpose of section 12 of the Finance Act [1895(c. 16)](/id/ukpga/1895/16?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (duty onproperty vested by Act, &c.), and
			shall not give rise to liability under an enactment about stamp duty orstamp duty land tax in respect of anything done (by any person) before thetransfer.
		Nothing in this Part constitutes arrangements for the purposes of—
			section 42(2) of the Finance Act [1930 (c.28)](/id/ukpga/1930/28?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (relief fromstamp duty),
			section 27(3) of the Finance Act [1967 (c.54)](/id/ukpga/1967/54?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (stamp duty),or
			paragraph 2 of Schedule 7 to the Finance Act [2003 (c.14)](/id/ukpga/2003/14?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (relief fromstamp duty land tax).

Operation of successor company
	Pre-sale issue of shares, &c. to government
		The successor company shall comply with any request of the Secretary ofState to issue securities to—
			the Secretary of State, or
			a person nominated by the Secretary of State.
		A request under subsection (1) may include provision about—
			the nature and nominal value of securities to be issued;
			timing; 
			terms of issue.
		A request under subsection (1) requiring the issue of shares shall specifythe nominal value of the shares to be issued; and the shares—
			shall be issued as fully paid,
			shall be treated for the purposes of the Companies Act [1985 (c.6)](/id/ukpga/1985/6?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") as having beenpaid up by virtue of payment of their nominal value in cash, and
			shall be treated for the purposes of the Corporation Tax Acts as if theyhad been issued wholly in consideration of a subscription of an amount equalto their nominal value.
		A debenture issued in accordance with a request under subsection (1) shallbe treated for the purposes of the Corporation Tax Acts as if it had beenissued wholly in consideration of a loan of an amount equal to the principalsum payable under the debenture.
		A request under subsection (1)—
			may be made before, on or after the appointed day, but
			may not be made after the successor company has ceased to be wholly ownedby the Crown.
		The Secretary of State shall not make a request under subsection (1)without the consent of the Treasury.
		Where a security is issued in accordance with a request under subsection(1) to the Secretary of State or his nominee, neither the Secretary of Statenor his nominee may dispose of the security without the consent of theTreasury.
	Accounts 
		This section applies for the purposes of statutory accounts prepared by thesuccessor company.
		The transfer effected by section 2(1) shall be treated as having—
			occurred immediately after the end of the last complete accounting year ofthe Horserace Totalisator Board, and
			transferred all property, rights and liabilities to which the Board wasentitled or subject immediately before the end of that year.
		For the purpose of subsection (2)(b) in its application to accounts of thesuccessor company the value of an asset, or the amount of a liability, ontransfer shall be taken as the value or amount assigned for the purposes ofthe corresponding accounts of the Board for its last complete accounting year.
		The amount to be included in the accounts in respect of an asset orliability shall be determined as if anything done by the Board had been doneby the successor company.
		An amount included in the accounts for the Board’s last complete accountingyear as accumulated realised profits retained by the Board shall be treated asif realised and retained by the successor company.
		Before the preparation of the successor company’s first set of statutoryaccounts for a complete accounting year, sections 270 to 276 of the CompaniesAct [1985 (c. 6)](/id/ukpga/1985/6?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")(distribution: justification by reference to accounts) shall apply as if thesuccessor company had prepared accounts for the relevant period in accordancewith the preceding provisions of this section.
		In this section “statutory accounts” means accounts prepared for thepurpose of a provision of the Companies Act 1985.
	Shadow directors
		While the successor company is wholly owned by the Crown, neither theSecretary of State nor the Treasury shall be treated as a shadow director ofthe successor company for the purpose of any provision of the Companies Act1985.

Post-transfer control of horserace pool betting
	Exclusive licence
		The Gaming Board shall, if the Secretary of State so requires, issue to thesuccessor company a licence (referred to in this Part as “the exclusivelicence”) granting the successor company the right—
			to carry on pool betting business (in any form) in connection with horseraces on approved horse racecourses,
			by way of business to receive or negotiate bets in connection with horseraces on approved horse racecourses on terms that all or part of the winningsshall be calculated or regulated directly or indirectly by reference to theamounts or rates of payments or distributions in respect of winning bets madeby way of pool betting, and
			to provide facilities in relation to a matter mentioned in paragraph (a) or(b).
		The exclusive licence shall, unless revoked under subsection (7), haveeffect for the period of seven years beginning with the date of issue.
		In requiring the issue of the exclusive licence the Secretary of State mayspecify terms or conditions of the licence.
		The Secretary of State—
			may require the issue of the exclusive licence before, on or after theappointed day,
			may require the issue of the exclusive licence after the successor companyhas ceased to be wholly owned by the Crown, and
			may not require the issue of the exclusive licence more than once.
		While the exclusive licence has effect—
			the successor company may authorise one or more other persons to doanything that the successor company is authorised to do by the exclusivelicence, and
			a person other than the successor company may not do anything that thesuccessor company is authorised to do by the exclusive licence, except inaccordance with an authorisation under paragraph (a).
		An authorisation under subsection (5)(a) may be given on terms andconditions; which may, in particular, include provision—
			for payment to or by the successor company;
			for agency or commission;
			about facilities to be provided by the successor company under subsection(1)(c).
		The Gaming Board—
			may make an order revoking the exclusive licence if they think that a termor condition of the licence has been breached, and
			shall make an order revoking the exclusive licence if the Secretary ofState so directs.
		A direction of the Secretary of State under subsection (7)(b) shall specifythe reasons for the direction.
		An order revoking the exclusive licence—
			must specify the reasons for the revocation (or, in the case of revocationpursuant to a direction under subsection (7)(b), the reasons for the directionspecified under subsection (8)), and
			shall take effect at such time as the order may specify.
		The Secretary of State may require revocation under subsection (7)(b) onlywhile the successor company is wholly owned by the Crown.
		The exclusive licence may not be—
			renewed, or
			issued or revoked otherwise than in accordance with subsection (1) or (7).
	Section 8: supplemental
		In considering whether to require the Gaming Board to issue or revoke theexclusive licence the Secretary of State shall consider whether the issue orrevocation—
			would be in the best interests of members of the public who are in thehabit of placing bets on horse races;
			would be in the best interests of the sport of horse racing;
			would promote the objectives of—
			preventing betting from being a source of crime or disorder, beingassociated with crime or disorder or being used to support crime,
			ensuring that betting is conducted in a fair and open way, and
			protecting children and other vulnerable persons from being harmed orexploited by betting.
		While the exclusive licence has effect—
			sections 4(1) and 4A(1) of the Betting, Gaming and Lotteries Act [1963 (c.2)](/id/ukpga/1963/2?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (restriction onpool betting) (as substituted by section 10 of this Act) shall not apply inrelation to anything done—
			by the successor company in pursuance of the exclusive licence, or
			in accordance with an authorisation under section 8(5)(a) above, and
			nothing in section 4 or 4A of that Act shall prejudice the generality ofsection 8(5)(b) above.
		While the exclusive licence has effect—
			the successor company or a person authorised under section 8(5)(a) abovemay apply under section 9(2) of that Act for the grant or renewal of a bettingoffice licence authorising the use of premises for carrying on activity inaccordance with the exclusive licence,
			a betting office licence under section 9(2) of that Act shall not authorisethe use of premises for doing anything prohibited by section 8(5)(b), and
			section 9(1) of that Act disapplies section 1(1) of that Act only inrelation to activity authorised by a betting office licence.
		While the exclusive licence has effect—
			the successor company shall not be treated as a bookmaker for the purposesof that Act by virtue of anything done in accordance with the exclusivelicence, and
			a person authorised under section 8(5)(a) above shall not be treated as abookmaker for the purposes of that Act by virtue of anything done inaccordance with the authorisation.
		A person who acts in contravention of section 8(5)(b) above shall betreated as having committed an offence under—
			section 4(1) of that Act, in the case of anything done on a track, or
			section 4A(1) of that Act, in the case of anything done otherwise than on atrack,
				whether or not he otherwise would have committed the offence.
		If a person commits or threatens a breach of section 8(5)(b), the successorcompany may (whether or not criminal proceedings are instituted against him byvirtue of subsection (5) above) proceed against him in the High Court or acounty court for damages or such other relief as the court thinks appropriate.
		Subsection (6) is subject to—
			Civil Procedure Rules, and
			section 1 of the Courts and Legal Services Act [1990 (c.41)](/id/ukpga/1990/41?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (allocation ofbusiness between High Court and county courts).
	Control when no exclusive licence
		For section 4 of the Betting, Gaming and Lotteries Act [1963 (c.2)](/id/ukpga/1963/2?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (restriction onpool betting) substitute—
		“4Restriction on pool betting on track
			A person commits an offence if he carries on pool betting business on atrack unless subsection (2), (3) or (5) applies.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business which is in connectionwith horse racing and which is carried on—
				by the holder of a bookmaker’s permit,
				on an approved horse racecourse,
				on a day on which one or more horse races take place on the racecourse, and
				in accordance with Part 2 of Schedule 1A.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business in connection with horseracing carried on—
				on an approved horse racecourse, and
				in accordance with a notice (to be known as a “point-to-point exemptionnotice”) issued by the Gaming Board under this subsection.
			A point-to-point exemption notice—
				may be issued by the Gaming Board in response to an application in writing,
				must relate to horse racing to be carried on along a single coursespecified in the notice,
				must specify a maximum number of days, not exceeding 7, on which horseracing may be carried on in reliance on the notice,
				may specify other conditions which relate to—
				the operation of a totalisator,
				the publication of terms on which pool bets may be made (and a conditionmay, in particular, relate to minimum stakes, or deductions), or
				compliance with terms published under sub-paragraph (ii),
				must specify a calendar year during which the notice has effect, and
				must be issued before the beginning of that year.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business which is in connectionwith dog racing and which is carried on—
				on a dog racecourse which is a licensed track, and
				by means of a totalisator operated—
				in accordance with section 16, and
				by the occupier of the track or by a person authorised by him in writing.
		ARestriction on pool betting off track
			A person commits an offence if he carries on pool betting businessotherwise than on a track, unless subsection (2), (3) or (4) applies.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business which is in connectionwith horse racing and which is carried on—
				by the holder of a bookmaker’s permit, and
				in accordance with Part 2 of Schedule 1A.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business which is carried on by aperson registered for the purpose of this subsection (in this Act referred toas a “registered pool promoter”); and Schedule 2 to this Act (registration andconduct of business) shall have effect.
			This subsection applies to pool betting business carried on in accordancewith a licensed inter-track betting scheme.
		BRegulation of horserace pool betting
			Schedule 1A (which provides for the regulation of pool betting business inconnection with horse racing) shall have effect.
			Subsection (3) applies where—
				a condition imposed by Part 2 of that Schedule requires or may require aperson to act after the conclusion of a race or set of races in relation towhich he conducts pool betting business, and
				the person fails, in respect of a matter wholly or partly relating to thatrace or set of races, to comply with the condition after that conclusion.
			The pool betting business carried on by the person in relation to the raceor set of races shall be treated as not having been carried on in accordancewith Part 2 of that Schedule.
			Subsection (5) applies where a person who has received or negotiated betsmade by way of pool betting in connection with horse racing fails to complywith a requirement of Part 3 of that Schedule.
			Any pool betting business which was carried on by the person and to whichthe requirement was or might have been relevant shall be treated as not havingbeen carried on in accordance with Part 2 of that Schedule.”
			After Schedule 1 to that Act (bookmakers' permits, &c.) insert the Schedule1A set out in Schedule 1 to this Act (regulation of horserace pool betting).
			Sections 281 and 282 of the Criminal Justice Act [2003 (c.44)](/id/ukpga/2003/44?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (increases inmaximum terms of imprisonment) shall apply to the Betting, Gaming andLotteries Act [1963 (c. 2)](/id/ukpga/1963/2?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") as amended by this section.

General
	Preparatory work by the Tote
		The Horserace Totalisator Board may do anything that it or the Secretary ofState thinks necessary or expedient in connection with—
			a provision of this Part,
			the operation of the successor company on or after the appointed day, or
			the listing, issue, sale or other disposal of securities of the successorcompany or a company associated with it.
		The Board shall so far as is reasonably practicable comply with—
			any request of the Secretary of State to provide information or assistancein connection with a matter specified in subsection (1)(a) to (c), and
			any direction of the Secretary of State made in connection with a matterspecified in subsection (1)(a) to (c).
		Before making a request or giving a direction under subsection (2) theSecretary of State shall consult the Board.
	Interpretation 
		In this Part “the Gaming Board” means the Gaming Board for Great Britain(established under section 10 of the Gaming Act [1968 (c.65)](/id/ukpga/1968/65?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		For the purposes of this Part a company is wholly owned by the Crown if allits shares are held by the Crown.
		For the purposes of subsection (2) shares are held by the Crown if they areheld—
			by a Minister of the Crown,
			by the nominee of a Minister of the Crown, or
			by a company of which all the shares are held by the Crown.
		In this Part “securities” means shares (including stock), debentures, bondsand other securities, whether constituting a charge on the assets of a companyor not.
		An expression used in this Part which is given a meaning by the CompaniesAct [1985 (c. 6)](/id/ukpga/1985/6?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") forgeneral purposes of that Act shall have the same meaning for the purposes ofthis Part.
		An expression used in this Part and in the Betting, Gaming and LotteriesAct [1963 (c. 2)](/id/ukpga/1963/2?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")shall have the same meaning in this Part as in that Act.
	Consequential amendments
		Schedule 2 (consequential amendments) shall have effect.
	Extent 
		This Part shall not extend to Northern Ireland.

Part 2Abolition of the Horserace Betting Levy System
	Abolition of levy
		The Secretary of State may by order made by statutory instrument—
			repeal any of sections 24 to 30 of the Betting, Gaming and Lotteries Act1963 (levy);
			repeal a provision of the Horserace Betting Levy Act [1969 (c.14)](/id/ukpga/1969/14?view=plain "Go to item of legislation");
			repeal a provision of the Horserace Betting Levy Act [1981 (c.30)](/id/ukpga/1981/30?view=plain "Go to item of legislation");
			provide for the Horserace Betting Levy Board to cease to exist.
		An order under subsection (1) may—
			repeal different provisions at different times;
			repeal a provision generally or only to a specified extent;
			make consequential provision (which may include provision amending orrepealing an enactment, in addition to the provision made by section 17 andSchedule 4).
		An order under subsection (1) may make transitional provision or savings,which may include provision—
			modifying the effect of a provision pending its repeal;
			about the conduct of the Horserace Betting Levy Board pending the repeal ofsection 24 of the Betting, Gaming and Lotteries Act 1963;
			about the conduct of the Bookmakers' Committee pending the repeal ofsection 26 of that Act;
			about the conduct of an appeal tribunal pending the repeal of section 29 ofthat Act.
		An order under subsection (1) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance ofa resolution of either House of Parliament.
	Property of the Levy Board
		In this Part “transfer scheme” means a scheme providing for the transfer ofspecified property, rights and liabilities of the Horserace Betting LevyBoard—
			to a person specified in the scheme, and
			at a time specified in the scheme.
		If the Secretary of State directs the Board to make and submit to theSecretary of State a transfer scheme—
			the Board shall comply with the direction,
			the Secretary of State may approve the scheme with or without modification,and
			if approved, the scheme shall have effect.
		A direction of the Secretary of State under subsection (2)—
			shall specify a date by which the transfer scheme is to be made;
			may specify property, rights or liabilities to be transferred by thetransfer scheme;
			may specify to whom property, rights or liabilities are to be transferredby the transfer scheme.
		The Secretary of State may make a transfer scheme if—
			the Board fails to comply with a direction under subsection (2), or
			the Secretary of State decides not to approve a scheme submitted under thatsubsection.
		A transfer scheme made under subsection (4) shall have effect.
		The Secretary of State shall not make or approve a transfer scheme underthis section unless satisfied that any property or rights transferred will beused or exercised for the purpose of—
			the improvement of breeds of horses,
			the advancement or encouragement of veterinary science or veterinaryeducation, or
			the improvement of horse racing.
		Schedule 3 (which makes supplementary provision in connection withdirections and schemes under this section) shall have effect.
	Consequential amendments
		The Secretary of State—
			may bring this section into force by provision included in an order madeunder section 15(1), and
			shall not make an order under section 15(1)(d) providing for the HorseraceBetting Levy Board to cease to exist unless the order also makes provision, oran earlier order under section 15(1) has made provision, bringing this sectioninto force at or before the time when that Board ceases to exist.
		Schedule 4 (consequential amendments) shall have effect.
		A certificate of approval issued under section 13 of the Betting, Gamingand Lotteries Act [1963 (c. 2)](/id/ukpga/1963/2?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") before the coming into force of this section (“commencement”)—
			shall continue to have effect after commencement as if issued by the GamingBoard for Great Britain under that section as amended by Schedule 4,
			may be revoked by the Gaming Board for Great Britain, and
			shall expire at the end of the period of three years beginning with thedate of commencement (but without prejudice to the power to issue a newcertificate).
	Tax 
		The Treasury may make regulations providing—
			for a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, inrespect of anything done under or in consequence of a transfer scheme;
			for anything done under or in consequence of a transfer scheme to have ornot have a specified consequence, or to be treated in a specified way, for thepurposes of a tax provision;
			for anything done in connection with, or done by a person with rights inconnection with, anything that was at any time transferred under a transferscheme, to have or not have a specified consequence, or to be treated in aspecified way, for the purposes of a tax provision;
			for a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, inrespect of anything transferred under a transfer scheme;
			for anything transferred under a transfer scheme to be treated in aspecified way for the purposes of a tax provision;
			for the withdrawal of relief (whether or not granted by virtue of theregulations), and the charging of tax, in connection with anything done underor in consequence of a transfer scheme where a specified event occurs, orspecified conditions are satisfied, whether on or after the commencement ofthe scheme;
			for a power under this Part, or anything done in exercise of a power underthis Part, to have or not have a specified consequence, or to be treated in aspecified way, for the purposes of a tax provision.
		In subsection (1) “tax provision” means a provision of an enactment aboutincome tax, corporation tax, capital gains tax, stamp duty, stamp duty landtax or stamp duty reserve tax.
		Regulations under this section—
			shall be made by statutory instrument, and
			shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either Houseof Parliament.
	Interpretation: “enactment”
		In this Part “enactment” includes an Act of the Scottish Parliament.
	Extent 
		This Part shall not extend to Northern Ireland.

Olympic Lotteries
	Licensing of Olympic Lotteries
		A licence under section 6 of the National Lottery etc. Act [1993 (c.39)](/id/ukpga/1993/39?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (licenceauthorising a body to promote lotteries as part of the National Lottery) maydesignate a lottery to which the licence relates as an Olympic Lottery.
		A licence under section 5 of that Act (licence to run the National Lottery)must include provision—
			for determining in respect of any period the proportion of proceeds oflotteries forming part of the National Lottery that is attributable to OlympicLotteries, or
			enabling the National Lottery Commission to determine that proportion inrespect of any period.
		A designation under subsection (1) may be made only while provision undersubsection (2) has effect.
		In respect of a licence under section 5 of that Act that has effect whenthis section comes into force—
			the Commission shall, after consulting the licensee, vary the licence so asto introduce provision of a kind specified in subsection (2)(a) or (b) above,and
			the variation shall take effect at such time as the Commission shallspecify (whether or not the licensee consents).
	Timing 
		This section applies to a licence under section 6 of the National Lotteryetc. Act [1993 (c. 39)](/id/ukpga/1993/39?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") which designates a lottery to which the licence relates as anOlympic Lottery.
		A licence to which this section applies must include a conditionprohibiting the promotion of an Olympic Lottery unless the Secretary of Statehas by order declared that the International Olympic Committee has electedLondon as the host city for the 2012 Olympic Games.
		Subsection (4) applies if the Secretary of State by order declares—
			that the International Olympic Committee has elected a city other thanLondon as the host city for the 2012 Olympic Games, or
			that the election of London by the International Olympic Committee as thehost city for the 2012 Olympic Games has been revoked.
		Where this subsection applies—
			a licence to which this section applies shall cease to have effect in sofar as it relates to an Olympic Lottery on such date as may be specified inthe order under subsection (3), and
			the National Lottery Commission may not grant a licence to which thissection applies.
		If the Secretary of State by order specifies a date as the termination datefor the purposes of this section—
			any licence to which this section applies that has effect immediatelybefore the termination date shall cease to have effect on that date in so faras it relates to an Olympic Lottery, and
			the National Lottery Commission may not grant a licence to which thissection applies in respect of a period of time falling wholly or partly on orafter the termination date.

Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund
	The Fund
		There shall be a fund maintained under the control and management of theSecretary of State and known as the Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund.
	Payments into Fund from lottery proceeds
		Where a sum is required by virtue of section 5(6) of the National Lotteryetc. Act [1993 (c. 39)](/id/ukpga/1993/39?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") (as substituted by section 34 of this Act) to be paid into theNational Lottery Distribution Fund out of proceeds of lotteries in respect ofa period, such proportion of that sum as is determined in accordance withsection 21(2) or (4) of this Act to be attributable to Olympic Lotteries shallbe paid instead into the Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund.
		Section 9(3) of that Act (as substituted by section 34 of this Act) shallhave effect in relation to the Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund and sums dueto be paid into it as it has effect in relation to the National LotteryDistribution Fund and sums due to be paid into it.
	Payments into Fund from National Lottery Distribution Fund
		The Secretary of State may make an order permitting the Secretary of Stateto make payments from the National Lottery Distribution Fund into the OlympicLottery Distribution Fund.
		A payment by virtue of an order under subsection (1) shall be treated as ifpaid out of money allocated for such of the purposes listed in section 22(3)of the National Lottery etc. Act 1993 (apportionment of money in DistributionFund) as the order shall specify.
		Before making an order under subsection (1) the Secretary of State shallconsult each of the bodies for the time being mentioned in section 23 of thatAct.
	Payments out of Fund
		The Secretary of State may pay sums from the Olympic Lottery DistributionFund to the Olympic Lottery Distributor.
		The Secretary of State may make regulations permitting payments from theOlympic Lottery Distribution Fund—
			in respect of expenses of the Secretary of State in connection withfunctions under this Part;
			in respect of expenses incurred or to be incurred by the National DebtCommissioners in making investments under section 27;
			into the National Lottery Distribution Fund;
			to the Greater London Authority;
			to the National Olympic Committee;
			into the Consolidated Fund for the purpose of meeting payments made or tobe made under paragraph 10 of Schedule 2A to the National Lottery etc. Act1993 (expenses of National Lottery Commission).
		Regulations by virtue of subsection (2)(a) and (b) shall permit paymentonly with the consent of the Treasury.
		Regulations by virtue of subsection (2)(c) shall in respect of each paymentspecify, or enable the Secretary of State to specify, whether it is to be—
			treated as having been paid into the National Lottery Distribution Fund byvirtue of section 5(6) of the National Lottery etc. Act [1993 (c.39)](/id/ukpga/1993/39?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (generalpayments into fund), or
			allocated entirely for expenditure on or connected with sport and held inaccordance with section 23(2) of that Act (distributing bodies for sports).
		Regulations by virtue of subsection (2)(c) may, in respect of a paymentallocated in accordance with subsection (4)(b) provide, or enable theSecretary of State to provide, for section 23(2) of that Act to apply withspecified modifications (which may, in particular, include modificationsreducing a distributor’s share to nil).
		Money paid to the Greater London Authority by virtue of subsection (2)(d)may be used by the Authority for any purpose for which it is authorised toincur expenditure.
	Investment 
		Money in the Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund may be paid to the NationalDebt Commissioners and invested by them.
		Proceeds of an investment under this section—
			may be re-invested by the National Debt Commissioners, and
			unless re-invested, shall be paid into the Olympic Lottery DistributionFund.
		In exercising a function under this section the National Debt Commissionersshall comply with any direction of the Treasury.
	Winding up
		The Secretary of State may by order make provision for the winding up ofthe Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund.
		An order under this section shall provide, in particular, for any money inor due to the Olympic Lottery Distribution Fund to be paid into the NationalLottery Distribution Fund.
		An order under this section shall in respect of any payment specify, orenable the Secretary of State to specify, whether it is to be—
			treated as having been paid into the National Lottery Distribution Fund byvirtue of section 5(6) of the National Lottery etc. Act 1993 (general paymentsinto fund), or
			allocated entirely for expenditure on or connected with sport and held inaccordance with section 23(2) of that Act (distributing bodies for sports).
		Provision by virtue of subsection (3)(b) may provide for section 23(2) ofthat Act to apply with specified modifications (which may, in particular,include modifications reducing a distributor’s share to nil).

Olympic Lottery Distributor
	The Olympic Lottery Distributor
		There shall be a body corporate known as the Olympic Lottery Distributor.
		Schedule 5 (which makes provision in relation to the Distributor) shallhave effect.
	Distribution 
		The Olympic Lottery Distributor shall distribute money received, whetherunder section 26 or otherwise, by way of grant or loan (subject to Part 3 ofSchedule 5).
		The Distributor may make a grant or loan only if it considers it necessaryor expedient for the purpose of or in connection with—
			the provision of facilities which are necessary or expedient if London isto be the host city of the 2012 Olympic games, or
			any other service or function which it is necessary or expedient to provideor undertake if London is to be the host city of the 2012 Olympic Games.
		In exercising its functions under this section the Distributor shall haveregard to—
			the Olympic Charter, and
			any agreement entered into by or on behalf of the International OlympicCommittee in the course of or in connection with the election of London as thehost city for the 2012 Olympic Games.
		A grant or loan may, in particular, fund expenditure related to theprovision of—
			facilities outside London;
			cultural and other events held in accordance with a provision of theOlympic Charter or in accordance with an agreement entered into by or onbehalf of the International Olympic Committee.
		A grant or loan may be subject to conditions which may, in particular,include conditions—
			as to repayment (with or without interest);
			providing for payments to be made only with the consent of a specifiedperson.
		The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that a specified class ofexpenditure is to be treated as—
			satisfying the requirements of subsection (2), or
			not satisfying those requirements.
	Distribution policy
		The Olympic Lottery Distributor shall comply with any requirement of theSecretary of State to—
			prepare a policy for the distribution of money under section 30, or
			review and revise the policy.
		A policy must, in particular—
			estimate the Distributor’s annual income,
			specify the sources of the income estimated,
			specify matters in respect of which the Distributor thinks that it will ormay make grants or loans, and
			estimate, where possible, the amount of grants or loans that theDistributor will or may make.
		A requirement under subsection (1) may include provision (which maysupplement or amplify subsection (2)) about—
			the form of the policy;
			the content of the policy.
		Before preparing or revising a policy the Distributor—
			shall submit a draft of the policy or revision to the Secretary of State,and
			shall consult—
			the National Lottery Commission,
			the Mayor of London,
			the National Olympic Committee, and
			the British Paralympic Association.
		The Distributor shall as soon as is reasonably practicable send a copy of apolicy or revision under this section to—
			the Secretary of State,
			the Mayor of London,
			the National Olympic Committee, and
			the British Paralympic Association.
		Where the Secretary of State receives a copy of a policy or revision undersubsection (5) he shall lay it before Parliament.
	Dissolution 
		The Secretary of State may by order make provision for the dissolution ofthe Olympic Lottery Distributor.
		An order under this section may, in particular—
			provide for the transfer of property, rights or liabilities of theDistributor to—
			the Secretary of State, or
			any other person;
			make provision enabling a person to receive anything transferred underparagraph (a) (and that provision shall have effect despite any otherenactment or instrument);
			establish a body corporate;
			make consequential, incidental or transitional provision which may, inparticular—
			provide for anything done by or in relation to the Distributor to haveeffect as if done by or in relation to another person;
			permit anything (which may include legal proceedings) which is in theprocess of being done by or in relation to the Distributor when a transfertakes effect, to be continued by or in relation to another person;
			provide for a reference to the Distributor in an instrument or otherdocument to be treated as a reference to another person.
		An order transferring a sum of money to the Secretary of State undersubsection (2)(a)(i) may require the Secretary of State to pay the sum intothe National Lottery Distribution Fund; and an order containing such provisionshall specify whether the payment is to be—
			treated as having been paid into the National Lottery Distribution Fund byvirtue of section 5(6) of the National Lottery etc. Act [1993 (c.39)](/id/ukpga/1993/39?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (generalpayments into fund), or
			allocated entirely for expenditure on or connected with sport and held inaccordance with section 23(2) of that Act (distributing bodies for sports).
		Provision by virtue of subsection (3)(b) may provide for section 23(2) ofthat Act to apply with specified modifications (which may, in particular,include modifications reducing a distributor’s share to nil).
		The Secretary of State may not make an order under this section providingfor the transfer of property, rights or liabilities to a person unless theperson has consented to the transfer.
		An order under this section—
			may transfer rights and liabilities relating to employees, but
			shall not affect the operation of the Transfer of Undertakings (Protectionof Employment) Regulations 1981 ([S.I.1981/1794](/id/uksi/1981/1794?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		The Secretary of State may not make an order by virtue of subsection (6)(a)unless satisfied that sufficient notice has been given to enable compliancewith any applicable requirement of those regulations.

Miscellaneous
	Interpretation 
		In this Part—
			a reference to the 2012 Olympic Games is a reference to—
			the Games of the Olympiad that are to take place in the year 2012, and
			except where the context otherwise requires, the Paralympic Games that areto take place in that year,
			“the National Olympic Committee” means the National Olympic Committee ofthe United Kingdom,
			“the Organising Committee” means the Organising Committee established bythe National Olympic Committee,
			“the Paralympic Games” means the events known by that name and inconnection with which the Organising Committee has functions by virtue of anagreement between that committee and the International Olympic Committee,
			“the Olympic Charter” means the Olympic Charter of the InternationalOlympic Committee, and
			any expression used in connection with the Olympic Games (including anexpression mentioned in this section) shall have the meaning which it has inor in accordance with the Olympic Charter of the International OlympicCommittee (as it has effect from time to time).
		A reference in this Part to the making of a loan includes a reference tothe provision of any other kind of financial assistance.

	Changes in Olympic procedure
		The Secretary of State may by order make such provision as he thinksnecessary or expedient in consequence of a change effected after the passingof this Act in the arrangements made by the International Olympic Committee inrelation to the Games of the Olympiad.
		An order under subsection (1) may, in particular, amend a provision of—
			this Part, or
			any other enactment.
	Regulations and orders
		Regulations or an order under this Part shall be made by statutoryinstrument.
		Regulations or an order under this Part—
			may make provision generally or only in relation to specified cases orcircumstances,
			may make different provision for different circumstances, and
			may include incidental, consequential or transitional provision.
		An order under section 22(2) or (3) shall be laid before Parliament.
		An order under section 25, 28 or 35 shall not be made unless a draft hasbeen laid before, and approved by resolution of, each House of Parliament.
		Any other order under this Part, and regulations under this Part, shall besubject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House ofParliament.
	Extent 
		This Part extends to—
			England and Wales,
			Scotland, and
			Northern Ireland.

Part 4General
	Repeals 
		The enactments listed in Schedule 6 are hereby repealed to the extentspecified.
	Money 
		There shall be paid out of money provided by Parliament—
			any expenditure of the Secretary of State in connection with this Act,
			any expenditure of the National Debt Commissioners in connection with thisAct, and
			any increase attributable to this Act in the sums payable out of moneyprovided by Parliament under another enactment.
	Commencement 
		The preceding provisions of this Act shall come into force in accordancewith provision made by order of the Secretary of State.
		An order under subsection (1)—
			may make provision that has effect generally or only for specifiedpurposes,
			may make different provision for different purposes,
			may include incidental, consequential or transitional provision, and
			shall be made by statutory instrument.
		Section 29 shall not be brought into force unless the Secretary of Statehas made an order under section 22(2).
	Extent 
		An amendment effected by this Act shall have the same extent as theenactment amended (or as the relevant part of the enactment amended).
		Sections 14, 20 and 37 are subject to subsection (1) above.
	Short title
		This Act may be cited as the Horserace Betting and Olympic Lottery Act 2004.
